citing_paper_authors: Haifeng, Wang | Hua, Wu | Zhanyi, Liu
raw_text: This idea is similar to translation lexicon extraction via a bridge language (Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002)
clean_text: This idea is similar to translation lexicon extraction via a bridge language (Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002).

raw_text: Nevertheless, SchaferandYarowsky (2002) have shown that these two techniques can be combined efficiently
clean_text: Nevertheless, Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) have shown that these two techniques can be combined efficiently.

citing_paper_authors: Nikesh, Garera | Chris, Callison-Burch | David, Yarowsky
raw_text: Schaferand Yarowsky, (2002) independently proposed using frequency, orthographic similarity and also showed improvements using temporal and wordburstiness similarity measures, in addition to context
clean_text: Schafer and Yarowsky, (2002) independently proposed using frequency, orthographic similarity and also showed improvements using temporal and wordburstiness similarity measures, in addition to context.

citing_paper_authors: Nikesh, Garera | Chris, Callison-Burch | David, Yarowsky
raw_text: Our setup we used cosine similarity: t ?wi =argmaxtwici1 ?r1+ci2 ?r2+ ... .+cin ?rn ?c2i1+c2i2+ ... +c2in ?r21+r22+ ... +r2nRapp (1999) used l1-norm metric after normalizing the vectors to unit length, Koehn and Knight (2002) used Spearman rank order correlation, and Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) use cosine similarity
clean_text: Our setup we used cosine similarity, Rapp (1999) used l1-norm metric after normalizing the vectors to unit length, Koehn and Knight (2002) used Spearman rank order correlation, and Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) use cosine similarity.

raw_text: Pivot Language methods were also used for translation dictionary induction (Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002), word sense disambiguation (Diab and Resnik, 2002), and so on
clean_text: Pivot Language methods were also used for translation dictionary induction (Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002), word sense disambiguation (Diab and Resnik, 2002), and so on.

raw_text: Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) induced translation lexicons for languages without common parallel corpora using a bridge language that is related to the target languages
clean_text: Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) induced translation lexicons for languages without common parallel corpora using a bridge language that is related to the target languages.

raw_text: For example, researchers have automatically developed translation lexicons by seeing if words from each language have similar frequencies, contexts (Koehn and Knight, 2002) ,burstiness, inverse document frequencies, and date distributions (Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002)
clean_text: For example, researchers have automatically developed translation lexicons by seeing if words from each language have similar frequencies, contexts (Koehn and Knight, 2002), burstiness, inverse document frequencies, and date distributions (Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002).

raw_text: Lexicon induction methods for closely related languages using phonetic similarity have been proposed by Mann and Yarowsky (2001) and Schafer and Yarowsky (2002), and applied to Swiss German data by Scherrer (2007) .The extraction of digital data from hand-drawn dialectological maps is a time-consuming task
clean_text: Lexicon induction methods for closely related languages using phonetic similarity have been proposed by Mann and Yarowsky (2001) and Schafer and Yarowsky (2002), and applied to Swiss German data by Scherrer (2007).

citing_paper_authors: Alexandre, Klementiev | Ann, Irvine | Chris, Callison-Burch | David, Yarowsky
raw_text: For instance, Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) demonstrated that word translations tend to co occur in time across languages
clean_text: For instance, Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) demonstrated that word translations tend to co occur in time across languages.

citing_paper_authors: Alexandre, Klementiev | Ann, Irvine | Chris, Callison-Burch | David, Yarowsky
raw_text: Various other similarity scores can be computed depending on the available monolingual data and its associated meta data (see ,e.g. Schafer and Yarowsky (2002))
clean_text: Various other similarity scores can be computed depending on the available monolingual data and its associated meta data (see, e.g. Schafer and Yarowsky (2002)).

raw_text: This can be accomplished as in Rapp (1999) and Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) by creating bag-of-words context vectors around both the source and target language words and then projecting the source vectors into the (English) target space via the current small translation dictionary
clean_text: This can be accomplished as in Rapp (1999) and Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) by creating bag-of-words context vectors around both the source and target language words and then projecting the source vectors into the (English) target space via the current small translation dictionary.

raw_text: Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) created lexicons between English and a target local language (e.g. Gujarati) using a related language (e.g. Hindi) as pivot
clean_text: Schafer and Yarowsky (2002) created lexicons between English and a target local language (e.g. Gujarati) using a related language (e.g. Hindi) as pivot.

raw_text: Pivot-based methods have also been used in other related areas, such as translation lexicon induction (Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002), word alignment (Wang et al, 2006), and cross language information retrieval (Gollins and Sanderson, 2001)
clean_text: Pivot-based methods have also been used in other related areas, such as translation lexicon induction (Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002), word alignment (Wang et al, 2006), and cross language information retrieval (Gollins and Sanderson, 2001).
